Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: A Novel Wireless Power Transmission Architecture for Devices Implanted in Human Bodies

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to verify a distributed power transmission architecture to deliver radio frequency power to devices implanted in human bodies. The proposed architecture aims to construct efficient and reliable wireless channels in complex in-body environments for power transfer. If proved feasible, it would fundamentally resolve a few problems associated with the state-of-the-art wireless charging technologies, including low efficiency, potential hazard to human health, and large and heavy apparatuses.

The intellectual merit is the proposed distributed power transmission architecture, which is potentially transformative to enable next-generation systems for wireless power delivery. Specifically, it has two major innovations. First, radio frequency power is transmitted via multiple antenna elements physically attached to a large area of skin and electrically matched to the skin. Second, the multiple antenna elements jointly behave as a retro-reflective beamformer: guided by the pilot signal sent from an implanted device, their radiations spatially converge to the target device with power intensities at all other locations below safety levels regulated for human.

The broader impacts include (i) promoting the contemporary Body Area Networks to the next level of integration; (ii) supporting both graduate and undergraduate students and provide them with excellent research opportunities; (iii) making constructive impacts to the science and engineering curricula at the three participating institutes; (iv) offering local high school students and teachers to participate in the proposed research activities; and (v) impacting both research and educational aspects of North Texas' high-tech industries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This collaborative research project involves three awards. The major research objective at University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center at Dallas (that is, associated with Award 1202240) is to verify the wireless power transmission technique developed at West Virginia University and University of Houston in practical biological environments.

This project started with testing several components designed by West Virginia University and University of Houston. Specifically, several planar antennas were tested and demonstrated capable of coupling electromagnetic waves into dielectric materials efficiently; an RF-to-DC converter was tested and the measured RF-to-DC conversion efficiency is higher than 50%; and the planar antenna and RF-to-DC converter were then integrated and tested. In this project, a range of experiments were conducted to verify the wireless power transmission scheme developed by West Virginia University and University of Houston to charge devices implanted in human bodies. Initially phantom sheets were stacked onto each other to emulate layered biological tissues, and realistic animal tissues were employed afterwards. Our experimental results are in excellent agreement with the numerical results collected by West Virginia University, and they successfully verify that wireless beams can be constructed and steered through phantoms/tissues via adjusting the feeding phases of the transmitting antennas. One experimental setup to validate wireless power transmission through animal tissues is shown in the attached photo. Further in this project, wireless power transmission in rectangular cavity that emulates practical surgery rooms was investigated. Our simulation and measurement results demonstrate RF-to-RF power transmission efficiency higher than 80% over a 20-MHz bandwidth around 420 MHz in a 1 m by 1 m by 1 m cubic cavity. Research findings of this project were published in 11 journal papers and 16 conference papers. Throughout the project period, this project’s progress and outcomes were disseminated over five national committees. Overall, this collaborative project constructs a platform for engineers and medical doctors to work closely with each other, which opens gates of enormous future research possibilities across the disciplinary boundaries.
